Thank you Mr. Chief Justice, may I please the court.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

Mr. Brusman, in order to prevail on your argument, as I understand your position, you have to first pick out a purpose that to identify that Congress was shooting at and then in effect conclude that it missed.

Well, the standard for testing the constitutionality of congressional legislation, as I understand it, is that the classification drawn by Congress has to bear a relationship to a legitimate legislative purpose and I think it is important to identify that purpose and to see whether the classification drawn relates to it.

But in identifying the purpose, you necessarily have to take the position that Congress had a purpose in mind but some of them misfired, somewhere between adopting that purpose and getting a law passed.

Not really, because in 1939, benefits were first provided for wives as a class and then in 1950, they were provided to wives with children in their care and it seems that the history is the problem that the benefits that were finally accorded to divorced wives did not begin until 1965.
But do you say we must conclude that each time Congress amended the act, it had the same purpose in mind?
Well, that purpose had not changed.
If I may just very briefly, Mr. Chief Justice.
